channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Enshrines ‘Xi Jinping Thought,’ Elevating Leader to Mao-Like Status
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, center, speaking on Tuesday during the closing ceremony of the party congress in Beijing.
item.description: The Communist Party has added the president’s name and ideas to its constitution, solidifying his position as China’s most powerful leader in decades.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China

item.title: Enmity Between Baghdad and Kurds Erupts in Deadly Clashes
item.media:description: Kurdish security forces withdrawing from a checkpoint in Altun Kupri, on the outskirts of Erbil, Iraq, the Kurdish regional capital, last week.
item.description: Both sides claim that they were attacked, and the Kurdish regional government says it expects a fresh Iraqi assault.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO

item.title: Across Myanmar, Denial of Ethnic Cleansing and Loathing of Rohingya
item.media:description: A Rohingya woman and her child returning to the Basara camp in Sittwe, the provincial capital of Rakhine State in Myanmar.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Claims that atrocities were staged, along with stark hate speech against Rohingya Muslims, are blaring out from social media and official statements.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Harvey Weinstein’s Italian Friend Is Now in the Eye of a Media Storm
item.media:description: Harvey Weinstein and Fabrizio Lombardo in 2007 at a screening of the film “Michael Clayton” at the Venice Film Festival.
item.description: Fabrizio Lombardo insisted he was a key employee of the movie producer in Italy. Former colleagues and women who’ve accused the mogul of harassment say otherwise.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: This Catalan Town Has Already Broken From Spain, Physically at Least
item.media:description: Catalan flags hanging from the municipal building in Llivia, a Spanish enclave within France that is connected to Spain by a narrow road.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: Llivia, a five-square-mile town, is a geographic and historical anomaly that has existed for more than 350 years as a Spanish enclave inside France.
item.dc:creator: LAURE FOURQUET

item.title: Only U.S. and Syria Now Oppose Paris Climate Deal, as Nicaragua Joins
item.media:description: President Trump announced in June that the United States would withdraw from the Paris climate accord.
item.description: The Central American country that once criticized the pact as not going far enough has hailed it as an important tool to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Australian Soldiers ‘Liked’ Facebook Page That Joked About Rape
item.description: A page that made light of rape and necrophilia was the latest embarrassment for the military, which critics say has a persistent culture of misogyny.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Kenya’s Supreme Court to Hear Last-Minute Petition on Election Rerun
item.media:description: Supporters of the Kenyan opposition leader Raila Odinga fleeing from the police at an attempted protest in the capital, Nairobi, on Tuesday.
item.description: Judges could postpone the vote scheduled for Thursday after the main opposition candidate withdrew and officials alleged interference.
item.dc:creator: JINA MOORE

item.title: Tillerson in Kabul? Two Photos Lead to Many Questions
item.media:description: The photo released by the office of Afghanistan’s president, where a clock above the television sets was removed.
item.media:credit: Office of the President of Afghanistan
item.description: A secret meeting between Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson and the Afghan president was said to take place in Kabul. Photographs told another story.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: China’s ‘Chairman of Everything’: Behind Xi Jinping’s Many Titles
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping at a military parade in Inner Mongolia in July. Many of his titles relate to the military and national security.
item.description: Mr. Xi has used a bureaucrat’s savvy to cement his control, inventing titles and institutions.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: These Seven Men Now Run China
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China presided over the opening of the Communist Party Congress last week in Beijing.
item.description: President Xi Jinping announced the new lineup for China’s Politburo Standing Committee, the body that will determine policy for the next five years.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Europe Edition: Xi Jinping, Jeff Flake, Glyphosate: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: China Unveils New Leadership, With Xi Jinping More Powerful Than Ever
item.media:description: China’s new Politburo Standing Committee was introduced at the Great Hall of the People. The members are, from left, Han Zheng, Wang Huning, Li Zhanshu, President Xi Jinping, Premier Li Keqiang, Wang Yang and Zhao Leji.
item.description: The Communist Party declined to anoint a potential successor, prompting speculation Mr. Xi intends to break with tradition and rule beyond his second term.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China

item.title: Deep Cracks Appear in Venezuela’s Weakened Opposition
item.media:description: Henrique Capriles at a rally this month. On Tuesday, he called for an overhaul of the opposition alliance.
item.description: After elections that bolstered President Nicolás Maduro, the opposition leader Henrique Capriles threatened to pull out of the anti-Maduro alliance.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and ANA VANESSA HERRERO

item.title: Jeff Flake, Puerto Rico, World Series: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Russian Celebrity Opens Presidential Campaign
item.media:description: Ksenia Sobchak, who plans to run in the coming presidential election, at a news conference in Moscow.
item.description: At a packed news conference, Ksenia Sobchak said she spoke of a generation itching to challenge a corrupt political system and ultimately gain power.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: U.K. Parliament Asks: Did Russia Try to Sway Brexit Vote?
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May in Brussels last week to talk about Britain’s departure from the European Union.
item.description: Parliament is asking Facebook, Twitter and others about potential efforts by Moscow to influence voters, as it did in the U.S. and France.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Far-Right Upsets Tradition of Consensus in New German Parliament
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany faced criticism from former coalition partners during the first session of the newly elected Parliament.
item.description: A challenge by the Alternative for Germany party holds up the opening of the session, as the opposition criticizes Chancellor Angela Merkel.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Russia Blocks U.N. Move to Renew Syria Chemical Weapons Inquiry
item.media:description: Civil defense members inspecting the damage at a site hit by airstrikes in Khan Sheikhoun, Syria, in April.
item.description: The veto of the United States-sponsored measure cast fresh doubt on whether users of chemical weapons in the Syrian conflict will ever be held to account.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: U.S. Warning to Pakistan: Stop Backing Terrorism
item.media:description: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson, center right, with the Pakistani foreign minister, Khawaja Muhammad Asif, center left, in Islamabad on Tuesday.
item.description: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson, in a meeting with Pakistani leaders, urged them to stop giving money or shelter to terrorist groups.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Those Aussies Playing in the Croc Trap? ‘Idiots,’ Mayor Says
item.description: A picture shows four men splashing around inside a baited crocodile trap. They seem to be smiling. Officials in Queensland were not amused.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: How Climate Change Is Playing Havoc With Olive Oil (and Farmers)
item.media:description: Harvesters gathering olives at Capezzana, the Contini Bonacossi family estate in Prato, Italy.
item.media:credit: Massimo Berruti for The New York Times
item.description: Extreme weather is making olive oil production far more erratic just as global demand is growing. A summer heat wave in Europe was the latest calamity.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: China Is Said to Free Hong Kong Bookseller, but Family Says He’s Missing
item.media:description: Protesters in Hong Kong last year with pictures of Gui Minhai, third from left, and other missing booksellers. Their disappearances raised questions about the rule of law in the semiautonomous city.
item.description: Gui Minhai, who published potboilers about China’s leaders, disappeared from Thailand two years ago and later emerged in detention in China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Hong Kong Protest Leaders Are Freed on Bail to Pursue Appeal
item.media:description: The pro-democracy activists Joshua Wong, left, and Nathan Law leaving the Court of Final Appeal in Hong Kong on Tuesday after being granted bail.
item.description: Joshua Wong and Nathan Law, key figures in the democracy movement, are challenging the sentences that led allies to call them political prisoners.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Europe Edition: Donald Trump, Syria, Migrants: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:credit: Mike Stocker/South Florida Sun-Sentinel, via Associated Press
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Footsteps: Chasing the Spirit of a Fractured Spain Through García Lorca
item.media:description: The famous Paseo de los Tristes.
item.media:credit: Javier Luengo for The New York Times
item.description: The powerful voice of the Spanish poet and playwright Federico García Lorca is still one that binds this nation in the midst of its current struggles.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: China’s Entrepreneurs Squirm Under Xi Jinping’s Tightening Grip
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Xiao Jianhua and Wu Xiaohui, who have not been seen in months; Ren Zhiqiang, a tycoon who was put on probation as a Communist Party member; and Guo Wengui, a developer seeking political asylum.
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Reuters; Associated Press; James Estrin/The New York Times
item.description: The Communist Party increasingly asserts its authority over business leaders, weakening their drive to invest and eroding confidence in the country.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: U.S. Clears Bill Browder to Enter, Rebuking Russia
item.media:description: William F. Browder, a prominent investor who has led an international campaign to punish Russian human rights abusers.
item.description: Moscow put William F. Browder, a Kremlin critic, on an Interpol list of international fugitives. Hours later, he announced that his visa was restored.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Brazilian Police Kill a Spanish Tourist in Rio de Janeiro
item.description: Police officers shot at the car the tourist was riding in after it failed to stop at a police roadblock, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Argentina’s President Says Election Gains Bolster His Reform Plan
item.media:description: President Mauricio Macri of Argentina spoke to journalists after casting his vote in Buenos Aires on Sunday. On Monday, Mr. Macri hailed the election results as a show of support for his agenda.
item.description: President Mauricio Macri’s strong showing in midterm elections strengthens his hand to press forward with labor, pension and tax changes.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI

item.title: Rex Tillerson, Megyn Kelly, Saudi Arabia: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: U.S. Troops Ambushed in Niger Waited an Hour to Call for Help
item.media:description: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr. spoke to reporters on Monday about the deadly ambush in Niger this month that killed four American soldiers and four Nigeriens.
item.description: The Pentagon has not determined why the soldiers waited to seek backup. A top official said they might have thought they could withstand the deadly attack.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF and HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Scores of Bodies Are Found in Syrian Town After ISIS Retreats
item.media:description: Syrian soldiers and pro-government fighters in the recently retaken desert town of Qaryatayn, Syria, on Sunday.
item.description: An apparent mass killing is the latest example of the brutal reprisals that have taken place when territory changes hands in Syria’s multisided war.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Tillerson Visits Iraq to Chilly Reception Over His Remarks on Iran-Backed Militias
item.media:description: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson listens as Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq, center, speaks during their meeting in Baghdad on Monday.
item.description: After a quick visit to Afghanistan the secretary of state arrives in Baghdad, seeking to ease tensions with the Kurds and to isolate Iran.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: U.S. Threatens to Punish Myanmar Over Treatment of Rohingya
item.media:description: Newly arrived Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh at an informal settlement.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Washington imposes travel restrictions on Myanmar’s military leaders and threatens sanctions against those responsible for atrocities in Rakhine State.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Rohingya, Marawi, Xi Jinping: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: ISIS Threat in Philippines Spreads in Remote Battles
item.media:description: Members of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front preparing to battle Islamic State-inspired militants in the southern Philippines last month.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: Even after the defeat of jihadist forces in the city of Marawi, people on Mindanao tell of fierce battles with other Islamist cells.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Russian Journalist Stabbed, Renewing Fears of Attacks on Media
item.media:description: Police officers detained a man after the journalist Tatyana Felgenhauer was stabbed at the Echo of Moscow radio station on Monday.
item.media:credit: Vitaly Ruvinsky/Ekho Moskvy, via Associated Press
item.description: The deputy editor of the prominent station, Echo of Moscow, was assaulted by a knife-wielding man. The station said her injuries were not life threatening.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: What It Could Mean if China’s Leader Won’t Name an Heir
item.media:description: Souvenir plates in Beijing depicting President Xi Jinping of China, left, and the revolutionary leader Mao Zedong.
item.description: If no successors-in-waiting appear, that would raise speculation that Xi Jinping may try to keep power in some form after his second five-year term as president ends.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China

item.title: Price-Fixing Inquiry Moves From BMW to Daimler and Volkswagen
item.media:description: The Mercedes-Benz logo on the headquarters of Daimler in Stuttgart, Germany. European Union regulators are looking into whether the country’s three major vehicle manufacturers — BMW, Daimler and Volkswagen — colluded on the cost of auto parts.
item.description: After raiding BMW last week, European Union regulators looking into possible collusion over equipment costs searched Daimler and Volkswagen offices.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Beirut Journal: A Legacy of Lebanon’s War: ‘Land Mines’ Left by Beirut’s Dogs
item.media:description: A woman walking her employer’s dog in Beirut, Lebanon. A small band of Beirutis are trying to drag their city into the modern world of poop-scooping.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: Dog feces on city streets seems like a small problem, but as it turns out, it reflects many of Lebanon’s larger ones.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Rex Tillerson Pays Secret Visit to U.S. Air Base in Afghanistan
item.media:description: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson arriving at Bagram Airfield, Afghanistan, on Monday. The trip was kept secret until after he had left.
item.description: Mr. Tillerson did not risk the short trip to Kabul to visit the heavily fortified United States Embassy or Afghan presidential palace, as his predecessors have done.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: London Adds Charge for Older Diesel Vehicles to Fight Pollution
item.media:description: A traffic jam in central London. Drivers of older, polluting vehicles face an additional penalty.
item.description: It will now cost almost $30 to drive such cars in the center of the British capital, as the mayor cites “a health crisis” caused by poor-quality air.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK and JACK EWING

item.title: D.E.A. Says Hondurans Opened Fire During a Drug Raid. A Video Suggests Otherwise.
item.media:description: Honduran Navy officers patrol in Ahuas, Honduras, in 2012.
item.description: Now made public, the government’s surveillance video strongly suggests the agency’s account of a raid in Honduras, where four civilians died, was not accurate.
item.dc:creator: MATTATHIAS SCHWARTZ

item.title: Scenes From a D.E.A. Drug Raid Gone Wrong
item.description: Surveillance footage from 2012, published for the first time, shows four civilians being killed during a drug operation. Mattathias Schwartz, a journalist working with ProPublica, narrates as boats collide and gunfire erupts.

item.title: As Mattis Arrives in Philippines, Mop-Up in Marawi Is Declared Over
item.media:description: The southern Philippine city of Marawi on Monday. The government called the city “liberated” last week, and on Monday, the final militant holdouts were said to have been killed.
item.description: Jim Mattis, the United States defense secretary, said the Philippines had sent a “very necessary message” to militants in the war-torn southern city.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Europe Edition: Catalonia, Japan, Robert Mugabe: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Juan Carlos Hidalgo
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Argentina’s Leader, Mauricio Macri, Bolstered by Election Results
item.media:description: President Mauricio Macri of Argentina sharing a selfie with a supporter after casting his vote in midterm elections in Buenos Aires on Sunday.
item.description: Mr. Macri’s coalition picked up key seats in midterm elections that were seen as a barometer of the center-right leader’s first two years in power.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI
